text:
FDA performs important work under difficult conditions involving multiple new aqpproaches to developing therapeutics. These include precision medicine approaches, gene therapy, antisense modification of DNA/RNA, and use of biomarkers. Generally PDUFA goals for reauthorization that involve metrics refer to timelines for standard and priority review, with objectives for 90% achievement of time limits, there are also objectives for biomarkers, involvement of rare disease staff, use of Real World Evidence, and patient involvement, including in risk benefit analysis.

Recommendations:
1. Include metrics/tabular reports on success in using new data and methods-rare disease involvement/biomarkers/RWE
2. Include some case studies of successful use of drug evaluation in which comprehensive use of such new approaches
resulted in an expedited drug approval, especially for a serious unmet need.
3. Accelerate ways to use Real World Evidence before 2021. 2019 for contract work to find ways to use RWE is too slow.
4. Make recommendations to Congress if necessary to modify substantial evidence to include these new scientific approaches(biomarkers, etc) in addition to "adequate, well controlled" trials.

The PDUFA objectives for these areas using new scientific approaches should also incorporate metrics, as well as "lessons learned." That is reports and statistics of new drug approvals and NME decisions should incorporate a checklist of whether each of these areas was involved in the approval process. For drug NDA XX2016 or YY2017, a table could be created showing

Drug Decision/Approval/CRL/etc Date RareDiseaseStaff Biomarker Real World Patient Involvement Structured Risk
InvolvementUseEvidencein Review/AnalysisBenefit Assmt

Having such tables or checklists could help assess the degree to which each of these tools or new approaches to supplementing and supporting traditional approaches to evaluating whether "substantial evidence of effectiveness,"
in addition to placebo controlled trials, can be established to speed evaluation of new drugs based on such precision
medicine and biomolecular approaches to developing therapies. It is my understanding that the phasing in of a
structured risk benefit approach has already been adopted, and therefore for example the column on structured
risk benefit can be determined for each new drug. The FDA recently included such a structured risk benefit table
in its briefing materials for a DMD drug based on exon skipping, and should clearly be considering whether similar new therapies which offer the potential for treating diseases with serious unmet need should be approved in view of potential benefits if risks are low or minimized.

Among the areas which could be assessed at also the use of biomarkers. use of Real World Evidence, and involvement of rare disease staff. For example, careful use of Patient Record Outcomes (PROs) and Caregive Reported Outcomes (CROs)
should be assessed as part of the emphasis on both Real World Evidence and Patient Involvement.As a corollary, there should be increased use of patient registries and their data on natural history and disease course and progression. One such example of potentially useful real world evidence is the Caregiver report carefully compiled and reported at a recent Advisory Committee meeting on a DMD therapy for which quality of life and improvement in patient outcomes is a significant objective of the therapeutic drug under consideration, which may only slow progression, but enable better patient outcomes and avoidance of irreversible loss of function while waiting for a full cure.
Rare Diseases
The Rare Disease Program staff in CDER will be integrated into review teams for rare disease development programs and application review to provide their unique expertise on flexible and feasible approaches to studying and reviewing such drugs....innovative use of biomarkers,...non-traditional clinical development programs, use of adaptive study designs, evaluation of novel endpoints,...new approaches to statistical analysis and appropriate use of FDA's expedited development and review programs (i.e., Fast Track, Breakthrough, Priority Review, and Accelerated Approval).

Enhancing Use of Real World Evidence for Use in Regulatory Decision-Making
By end of FY 2018, FDA will complete one or more public workshop(s) with patients, biopharmaceutical companies and academia to gather input into issues related to Real World Evidence (RWE) ;
By end of FY 2019, FDA will initiate (or fund by contract), appropriate activities (e.g., pilot studies or methodology development projects) aimed at addressing key outstanding concerns and considerations in the use of RWE for regulatory decision making.
And by end of FY 2021, FDA will publish draft guidance on how RWE can contribute to the assessment of safety and effectiveness in regulatory submissions.
